instruction: How did the researchers determine that the visible, near-infrared, and shortwave infrared (Vis/NIR/SWIR) spectral bands were the best for monitoring within-field soybean yield using Sentinel-2 satellite remote sensing data and machine learning methods?
Output:
The researchers determined that the visible, near-infrared, and shortwave infrared (Vis/NIR/SWIR) spectral bands were the best for monitoring within-field soybean yield using Sentinel-2 satellite remote sensing data and machine learning methods through a series of evaluations and comparisons. 

They collected soybean yield maps using a combine harvester with a yield monitor in 15 fields across three farms in Parana State, southern Brazil. These yield maps served as ground truth data for comparison. 

They then obtained Sentinel-2 images, including spectral bands and eight vegetation indices, throughout the cropping season. These images were correlated with the recorded soybean yield maps to assess their performance in predicting yield.

The researchers found that pooling information across the cropping season yielded better results compared to using single images. Among the different spectral bands and vegetation indices, the Vis/NIR/SWIR spectral bands showed the best performance in predicting soybean yield.

To further validate their findings, the researchers compared the results obtained from the Sentinel-2 data with leaf-based hyperspectral reflectance data collected at the Brazilian National Soybean Research Center. They found that the field-, farm-, and global-based models developed using the Vis/NIR/SWIR bands showed similar trends to the leaf-based data.
